awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Performance GPU Cluster for Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphics Processing Unit(GPU)-acceleration) has become a useful, if not essential, tool for computational tasks in support of investigations across a wide range of disciplines, from data science to biological sciences to physical and social-science areas. Therefore, the addition of GPU-accelerated computing capacity comprising a cluster of hybrid GPU/CPU compute nodes to the HPC system, Hawk at Montclair State University provides critical support for research and education activities, across the Institution, which share the need for this capacity. The impact of each of these investigations is magnified by users’ access to the GPU-accelerated computing capacity provided by this System. Moreover, by serving as a focal point for high-performance, GPU-accelerated computing, the system stimulates and supports collaboration across disciplines by investigators as well as their external collaborators. In the setting of the university, a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution with a diverse student body, PIs, as well as other major users utilize this instrument in both undergraduate and graduate education activities that enhance the STEM education for these students, including a significant proportion who are first-generation students in higher education.  The instrument serves to both attract the interest of --and provide training in leading-edge computing to-- a diverse group of students in order to inspire and prepare them to be part of the future STEM workforce by providing `hands on’ access to GPU-accelerated HPC and the computing tools and techniques enabled by this platform.

The cluster of hybrid GPU/CPU (Computer Processing Units) compute nodes acquired under this award are integrated to the Hawk system. These nodes constitute a substantial and transformative expansion of computing capacity for research and education at Montclair State, which previously had no generally accessible GPU-accelerated HPC.  The utility of the cluster of compute nodes is significantly enhanced by leveraging the resources of the Hawk cluster. The System is configured to be accessible to not only PIs, but also to users across the Institution, as well as their external collaborators and supports multiple ongoing GPU-accelerated research activities including investigations in  (1) computing and data science, (2) biology and genomics, (3) geomorphology and land use, (4) computational mathematics, (5) applied mathematics, (6) business analytics, and (7) linguistics. These collaborations include the implementation of new techniques and approaches (e.g., machine learning and deep neural networks) to both emerging and long-standing problems in these disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
High-performance computing (HPC) plays a vital role in advancing research and education at Montclair State University. The development of a GPU-accelerated HPC system through this MRI funded project have transformed the University's computational capabilities, fostering breakthroughs across multiple disciplines. Below, we highlight the outcomes of this initiative, reflecting both its intellectual merit and broader impacts.

Intellectual Merit

The upgraded GPU-accelerated HPC system has enabled researchers to address complex problems across diverse scientific domains:

1.Research Advancements:

The GPU-accelerated HPC system has driven groundbreaking advancements across multiple disciplines. In biology and genomics, researchers have utilized GPU-powered models to analyze DNA sequences and identify transposable elements like Helitrons, shedding light on genome evolution. In artificial intelligence, novel frameworks for fake image detection and dynamic resource management models have expanded the boundaries of AI research. Distributed machine learning systems have also benefited significantly, with the development of innovative algorithms that reallocate data based on machine processing speeds, optimizing resource utilization and enhancing decentralized learning processes. Robotics innovations have included intelligent systems for human-robot collaboration and advanced object detection. Climate and environmental studies have leveraged AI and satellite imagery to promote renewable energy deployment, analyze offshore wind energy, and optimize urban sustainability. In healthcare, transfer learning-based models for COVID detection and audio-based tuberculosis diagnostics highlight the transformative potential of computational power in medical applications.

2.Interdisciplinary Impact: 

The Hawk HPC system has supported cross-disciplinary collaborations, enabling applications in bioinformatics, computational linguistics, sustainability analytics, environment and smart energy, psychology and beyond. It has become an indispensable tool for advanced simulations, machine learning applications, and data-intensive research.

3.Publication and Dissemination: 

The research outcomes have been disseminated widely, with over 30 peer-reviewed journal articles and conference presentations. These contributions advance scientific knowledge and demonstrate the system's pivotal role in addressing contemporary challenges.

Broader Impacts

The GPU-accelerated HPC system has had profound effects on education, collaboration, and societal challenges:

1.Educational Enrichment:

Students at Montclair State University, an access institution and Hispanic-Serving Institution, have gained hands-on experience with cutting-edge computational techniques. This aligns with the University’s mission to foster inclusivity and diversity in STEM. The system has been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses, expanding learning opportunities in Data Science, Applied Mathematics, and Computational Linguistics. Over 54 graduate students have utilized the system for theses and projects, equipping them with the skills to thrive in STEM careers.

2.Infrastructure Enhancement:

The Hawk cluster, originally established as a CPU-based system, has been significantly upgraded to include 27 NVIDIA GPUs. This transformation ensures scalability for future expansion and positions Montclair State at the forefront of computational research. User-friendly interfaces, such as Open OnDemand, and comprehensive training have made the system accessible to a broad range of users across disciplines.

3.Collaborative Growth. 

The project has fostered collaborations. At MSU, the number of major users has increased from 12 to 36, spanning disciplines such as Computer Science, Data Science, Applied Mathematics, Statistics, Biology, Earth and Environmental Science, Computational Linguistics, Chemistry and Biochemistry, Physics, Business Analytics, and Psychology. Additionally, collaborations have extended to external institutions such as Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, Fordham University, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, and Rutgers University. This extended network amplifies the impact of the Hawk cluster, enabling shared expertise and broader applications of its capabilities.

The GPU-accelerated HPC system has established itself as a cornerstone of research and education at Montclair State University. By supporting cutting-edge investigations, fostering collaboration, and enriching education. The system not only enhances the University's research capabilities but also prepares a diverse and inclusive future STEM workforce equipped to tackle the challenges of the modern world.
